Class CsvToJsonConverter

java.lang.Object
CsvToJsonConverter.CsvToJsonConverter
public class CsvToJsonConverter extends Object
Main class responsible for converting data from a CSV file (e.g., HCLEcatalog.csv) into a structured JSON format. It reads the CSV row by row, attempts to parse each row into appropriate entity types (Item, Document, Artifact, Person, Organization, Category, Material), creates corresponding objects using the defined POJO classes, establishes relationships between them based on predefined logic, collects unique entities and relationships using Sets, and finally writes the aggregated data into a JSON file (e.g., data.json) according to the JsonOutput structure. A log file (e.g., parsing.log) is generated to track the processing status and potential errors encountered for each CSV row.

  • Field Details

    • PERSON_REGEX_STRICT

      private static final Pattern PERSON_REGEX_STRICT
      Regex to identify a string likely representing a single person's name in a standard format. Matches common titles (Dr., Prof.), capitalized first/last names, optional middle name/initial, and common suffixes (Jr., Sr.). Used for identifying potential 'Person' entities in fields like 'Creator'.

    • PERSON_REGEX_LIST

      private static final Pattern PERSON_REGEX_LIST
      Regex to identify a string potentially containing a list of person names, separated by common delimiters (commas, semicolons, 'and', '&'). More lenient than PERSON_REGEX_STRICT. Used for parsing fields like 'Contributor' and 'AddlAuth' which might contain multiple names.

    • NAME_SPLIT_DELIMITER

      private static final Pattern NAME_SPLIT_DELIMITER
      Regex defining the delimiters used to split strings containing multiple names or identifiers. Matches whitespace around ',', ';', 'and', '&'. Used in conjunction with String.split(String).

  • Constructor Details

    • CsvToJsonConverter

      public CsvToJsonConverter()

  • Method Details

    • main

      public static void main(String[] args)
      Main entry point of the CSV to JSON conversion application. Defines file paths, initializes sets for storing unique entities and relationships, reads and parses the CSV file record by record, processes each record to create entities and relationships, and finally serializes the collected data into the output JSON file. Handles potential IOException during file operations.
      Parameters:
      args - Command line arguments (not currently used).

    • getRecordValue

      private static String getRecordValue(org.apache.commons.csv.CSVRecord record, String headerName)
      Safely retrieves a value from a CSVRecord using the header name. Checks if the header exists in the record's map before attempting to get the value, preventing IllegalArgumentException if the header is missing.
      Parameters:
      record - The CSVRecord object representing the current row.
      headerName - The case-insensitive name of the header/column to retrieve the value for.
      Returns:
      The string value from the specified column (trimmed by the parser configuration), or null if the column header is not found in the record or if the value is missing.

    • isNullOrNone

      private static boolean isNullOrNone(String s)
      Checks if a string is effectively null or empty, also considering common string representations of null like "None" or "NULL" (case-insensitive) after trimming whitespace.
      Parameters:
      s - The string to check.
      Returns:
      true if the string is null, empty/whitespace-only, or equals "None" or "NULL" (case-insensitive), false otherwise.

    • isNullOrEmpty

      private static boolean isNullOrEmpty(String s)
      Checks if a string is null or consists only of whitespace characters after trimming. This is a simpler check than isNullOrNone(String).
      Parameters:
      s - The string to check.
      Returns:
      true if the string is null or its trimmed version is empty, false otherwise.

    • processContributorField

      private static void processContributorField(String fieldContent, String relationshipBaseType, Artifact currentEntity, Set<Person> peopleSet, Set<Organization> orgSet, Set<Relationship> relSet, PrintWriter logWriter, int rowIndex)
      Processes a CSV field (like "Contributor" or "AddlAuth") that might contain one or more names, potentially a mix of persons and organizations, separated by delimiters. It attempts to parse each delimited part as a Person. If successful, a Person entity and the corresponding relationship are created. If parsing fails, or if the input doesn't look like a list of persons, it treats the part(s) as Organization(s) and creates entities and relationships accordingly. Logs warnings for parsing issues.
      Parameters:
      fieldContent - The raw string content from the CSV field.
      relationshipBaseType - The base type for the relationship (e.g., "developed", "collaborated"). This is adapted to "produced" for organizations if base is "developed".
      currentEntity - The core entity (Item, Document, Artifact) that is the object of the relationship.
      peopleSet - The set to add newly identified unique Person entities to.
      orgSet - The set to add newly identified unique Organization entities to.
      relSet - The set to add newly created unique Relationship objects to.
      logWriter - The PrintWriter for logging warnings or errors.
      rowIndex - The current CSV row index for logging context.

    • addPersonRelationship

      private static void addPersonRelationship(Person person, String relationshipType, Artifact currentEntity, Set<Relationship> relSet)
      Creates a Relationship linking a Person to the currentEntity.
      Parameters:
      person - The subject Person entity.
      relationshipType - The type of the relationship (e.g., "developed", "collaborated").
      currentEntity - The object Artifact/Item/Document entity.
      relSet - The set to add the new relationship to.

    • addOrganizationAndRelationship

      private static void addOrganizationAndRelationship(String orgName, String relationshipBaseType, Artifact currentEntity, Set<Organization> orgSet, Set<Relationship> relSet, PrintWriter logWriter, int rowIndex, boolean logAsNew)
      Creates an Organization entity from a name string, adds it to the provided set (if unique), and creates the corresponding Relationship linking the organization to the currentEntity. Adjusts the relationship type from "developed" to "produced" for organizations. Logs the identification of a new organization.
      Parameters:
      orgName - The name of the organization.
      relationshipBaseType - The base type for the relationship ("developed", "collaborated", etc.).
      currentEntity - The entity the organization is related to (the object of the relationship).
      orgSet - The set of unique Organizations to add the new one to.
      relSet - The set of unique Relationships to add the new one to.
      logWriter - The PrintWriter for logging.
      rowIndex - The current row index for logging context.
      logAsNew - Flag to indicate if finding this org name should be logged as 'newly identified'.

    • parsePerson

      private static Person parsePerson(String nameStr)
      Attempts to parse a single string potentially representing a person's full name into a Person object with separate name (first) and surname (last) fields. It first cleans the input string by removing common titles (Dr., Prof., Mr., Ms., Sir) and suffixes (Jr., Sr., III). Then, it splits the cleaned name by whitespace. If there are at least two resulting parts, the first part is assigned to person.name and the remaining parts (joined by spaces) are assigned to person.surname. Logs a warning if parsing fails to produce at least two name parts.
      Parameters:
      nameStr - The input string potentially representing a person's name (e.g., "Dr. John A. Smith, Jr.").
      Returns:
      A Person object with name and surname populated if parsing is successful (at least two name parts found after cleaning). Returns null if the string cannot be reliably parsed into a first and last name (e.g., empty after cleaning, only one part found), indicating it should likely be treated as an organization or logged as unparseable.
